author: nextblock
content:
One possible solution that I wanted to share with this group in the FB MEV-boost censor/blacklist/regulatory compliance debate is to have a set of "preference" criteria that a node operator can set and signal with.  A block producer can build a block to that specification if they bid for that block. The relay could remain neutral. For example, If I'm in a country and want to comply with government regulations that prohibit me from interacting with a blocked address I could select that attribute preference (e.g. OFAC compliant) in a public profile. The builder; knowing that one of my validators is due to produce the next block could assemble a block that meets the node operators preference criteria and certify to its construction when they submit the hash to the relay. The relay remains neutral. 

This public preference criteria could also be expanded to include other non-regulatory preferences such as "no sandwich attacks".  Ethereum would benefit by knowing exactly how much censoring of the blockchain there is by measuring the public preferences set.

author: slodkokwasny.
content:
I'm not acquainted with eth clients codebase, so this might be a silly idea, but maybe if transactions with most priority fee in the mempool contain over X priority fees, don't ask for a mev block and build a local one instead with the priority transactions.
=> where X is a value higher than profit from 99.9% of mev rewards. So you don't actually need to compare local/mev block and can instead just assume local is better.
When you are sanctioned, you can turn up your priority fee to 200 or whatever. Your transaction sits in the mempool because of the censorship. After some time, other sanctioned transactions stack up in the mempool, until their cumulative priority fee exceeds the X value and residential proposers start to ignore centralized MEV and include you in their blocks.
